div.head:
Embleme 10. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Give fire to fire, Mercury to Mercury, and you have enough.

lg.l: The worlds of whole frame depends upon this chainechain,
Like to its like, as ShepheardesseShepherdess to SwaineSwain:
These are the bounds of art, proceed noe higher,
Hermes to Hermes joyne, and fire to fire.
Vulcan makes Hermes fly, but Cynchia must
Bring him to tears, then yeild to her brothers lust.

div.head: Discourse 10.
div.ab:
If this saying be literally, it onely increasethincreases the quality of fire and Mer
cury, and introducethintroduces noe new quality in the subject: for every like being added
to its like makes a similar augmentation: and therefore Physicians affirme-
that contrary diseases are cured and taken away by contrary medicines,-
soe wee see that fire is extinguished by water, but sustained by adding
fire: The Poet is of the same opinion saying: Venus ragethrages in wine, fire in
fire: but it may be answered, that fire and fire, Mercury and Mercury are
very different one from another: for there are many kinds of fires with the
Philosophers, many allso of Mercury: Moreover the same heat and cold-
being distant onely in place or situation, differs from another of its owne-
kind, soe as to attract to it that which is like to itselfe, that heat fixed in-
any part is attracted and drawne forth by the same heat, and that the-
joyntsjoints being stupefydstupefied with the cold of winter, and allmost dead with cold
water, are restored if they be put into it, not by externall heat imediately
administredadministered: as indeed a greater light obscures the lesse, soe allso greater heat the
lesse, and greater cold the lesse: neverthelesse it is requisite for the externall
heat and cold to be lesse, than that which was before fixed or imprinted on the
parts or joyntsjoints, otherwise the same impression would be made, as before, and-
the like would be much more increased, than drawne out, by the like: for-
the drawing out of cold by cold water, and of fiery heat by heat is agreableagreeable to
nature, because every sudden mutation into a contrary is dangerous to it, and-
lesse acceptable, but that which is by little and little, and as it were by degrees
is tolerable: soe wee say, there is one internall fire, and is allready infixed-
and essentiall in the Philosophicall subject, and another externall, which may
allso be understood of Mercury: that is an internall fire Ã¦quivocallyequivocally because
of its fiery qualities, virtues, and operations, externall univocally: Externall fire
therefore must be given to the internall, and the like Mercury to Mercury,-
that the intention of the art may be completed: To mollify or mature any-
hard or crude thing by coction, wee use fire and water: for water dissolves-
hardnesse, and penetrates into the compact parts, heat adding strength and-
motion to it; as appears by example in the coction of Peas, which are of
themselves sound and hard, but doe swell, are broken, and reduced to a-
pulpe by water, the heat of fire rarefying the water by ebullition, and
making it of a more thinne or allmost airy substance: Soe the heat of
fire resolves the crude parts of fruit or flesh into water, and causethcauses them
to evaporate with it into aire: after the same manner fire and Mercury
here are fire and water, and the same, fire and Mercury are the mature
and crude parts, of which the crude are to be matured by coction, or the
mature purged from superfluityessuperfluities by the ministery of fire and water:-
Now that these are two fires, and two MercuryesMercuries principally and solely ne
cessary to the art, wee will here breifelybriefly demonstrate: Empedocles deter
mined two principles of all things, love, and variance, or freindship and dis
Discourse 10.
cord: that by variance corruptions were made, generations by love: such vari
ance is manifestly beheld between fire and water, fire causing water to eva
porate, if it can, water on the contrary extinguishing fire, if admitted to it:-
but for all that it is conspicuous that generations may be made of the same-
with some certaine freindship; for by heat a new generation of aire is made
of water, and by the same the induration of water into a stone, and soe
out of these two Elements as it were the first are made allso the other two,-
and by consequence the production of all things: Water was the matter-
of heaven, and of all corporall things: Fire, as the forme, movsmoves and in
forms this matter; soe this water or Mercury yeilds the matter, and fire-
Sulphur, the forme: which two, that they may come to operation, and
move themselves mutually by solution, coagulation, alteration, tinction,
and perfection, have need of externall helps, as instruments, without-
which noe effect could follow: For as a Smith effects nothing without-
hammer and fire, soe neither the Philosopher without his instruments,-
which are water and fire: And this water is called by some the water of-
clouds, as this fire occasioned fire: It is without doubt calldcalled the water of
clouds, because it is distillddistilled, as the dew of May, of most thinne parts: for-
as the dew of the sayd monethmonth being included in an eggshell is affirmed to
rayseraise the egge, or its continent, high by the heat of the Sunne, soe allso
this water of the clouds, or dew makes the Philosophers egge ascend, that
is, sublimes, exalts, and perfects it: The same water is allso most Sharp-
vinegar, which hath made a body a mere Spirit: for as vinegar is of dif
ferent qualityes, namely to penetrate to the bottomebottom, and astringe, soe
this water dissolves and coagulates, but is not coagulated, because it is-
not of a proper subject: Now this water is had from the fountainefountain of-
Parnassus, which contrary to the nature of other fountains is at the top- the. .
of a mountainemountain, made by the hoofehoof of the flying horse Pegasus.-
There must allso be actuall fire, which notwithstanding must be go
verned and qualifyed by its degrees, as by bridles. For as the Sunne-
procedingproceeding from Aries into Leo gradually increasethincreases heat to things-
growing, by approaching allwayes nearer, soe is it here necessary to be
done: for the Philosophers infant must be nourished by fire, as milke,
the more hee growesgrows, the more fruitfullfruitful. . . . . . . .
